revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox television | show_name = At the Movies | image = | caption = | picture_format = [[576i]] ([[Standard-definition television|SDTV]]) | runtime = 26 minutes per episode | starring = [[Margaret Pomeranz]]
[[David Stratton]] | country = Australia | language = English | producer = Claude Gonzalez | first_aired = 1 July 2004 | last_aired = 9 December 2014 | num_seasons = 11 | network = [[ABC (Australian TV channel)|ABC]] | website = http://abc.net.au/atthemovies/ }} '''''At the Movies''''' was an [[List of Australian television series|Australian television]] program on [[ABC (Australian TV channel)|ABC]] hosted by film critics [[Margaret Pomeranz]] and [[David Stratton]], where they discussed the films opening in theatres that week. [[File:Margaret Pomeranz.jpg|thumb|right|Host Margaret Pomeranz]] [[File:David Stratton.jpg|thumb|right|Host David Stratton]] ==History== The program, which began in mid-[[2004 in Australian television|2004]], is a continuation of the pair's earlier program ''[[The Movie Show]]'', which aired on [[SBS One]] from 1986 to 2004. The pair left SBS after expressing dissatisfaction with high-level decisions. The weekly half-hour program consists of film reviews and discussions as well as interviews with cast and crew members. The hosts also occasionally broadcast from film events such as the [[Cannes Film Festival]]. The pair's 25 years of presenting film reviews on television was celebrated in a special show on 26 October 2011, filmed before an audience and special guests, hosted by [[Cate Blanchett]] and [[Geoffrey Rush]].[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/arts/the-david-and-margaret-show/story-e6frg8n6-1226163130634 "The David and Margaret show"] by [[Graeme Blundell]], ''[[The Australian]]'' (15 October 2011) On 16 September 2014, Stratton and Pomeranz announced they would be retiring at the end of the 2014 series. The final episode aired on 9 December 2014{{cite news|title=Margaret Pomeranz and David Stratton roll end credits on 28-year film review partnership; ''At The Movies'' will not return to ABC in 2015|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-09-16/margaret-pomeranz-and-david-stratton-roll-end-credits/5747214|accessdate=16 September 2014|publisher=ABC News|date=16 September 2014}} and Stratton and Pomeranz said farewell to over 700,000 viewers, making it one of the most watched season finales on the ABC in the history of the station.[http://mumbrella.com.au/movies-wraps-726000-metro-viewers-267062 "At The Movies wraps with bumper 726,000 metro viewers"] by Dan Robbins, ''Mumbrella'' (5 July 2015) == 5 star films == Only seven films have achieved a "5 star" rating by both Pomeranz and Stratton.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/atthemovies/review/bystarrating/five.htm |title=Five-star movies |publisher = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] |accessdate=25 Dec 2013}} * ''[[Good Night, and Good Luck]]'' * ''[[Brokeback Mountain]]'' * ''[[No Country for Old Men (film)|No Country for Old Men]]'' * ''[[Samson and Delilah (2009 film)|Samson and Delilah]]'' * ''[[A Separation]]'' * ''[[Amour (2012 film)|Amour]]'' * ''[[Birdman (film)|Birdman or (the Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)]]'' In the previous SBS format, several films achieved 5 stars from both Margaret and David, including films such as ''[[Goodfellas]]'', ''[[The Thin Red Line (1998 film)|The Thin Red Line]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/movies/movie/thin-red-line|title=''The Thin Red Line''|publisher=[[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]]|accessdate=27 June 2015}} ''[[Schindler's List]]'',{{Cite web|title = Schindler's List: Review|url = http://www.sbs.com.au/movies/video/11672643842/Schindlers-List-Review|website = SBS Movies|publisher = [[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]]|accessdate = 2015-10-30}} ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/movies/movie/2001-space-odyssey |title=2001: A Space Odyssey |publisher = [[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]] |accessdate=6 July 2015}} ''[[Aliens (film)|Aliens]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/movies/video/11663939670/Aliens-Review |title=Aliens: Review |publisher = [[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]] |accessdate=7 July 2015}} ''[[Eyes Wide Shut]]'',.{{Cite web|title = Eyes Wide Shut Review|url = http://www.sbs.com.au/movies/review/eyes-wide-shut-review|accessdate = 2015-09-25}} ''[[Russian Ark]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/movies/review/russian-ark-review-one-take-wonder-most-amazing-achievement|title=''Russian Ark review: One-take wonder is a most amazing achievement''|publisher=[[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]]accessdate=7 April 2016}} ''[[The Thin Blue Line]],'' http://www.sbs.com.au/programs/video/11708995656/The-Thin-Blue-Line-Review ''[[Evil Angels (film)|Evil Angels]],''{{Cite news|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/movies/movie/evil-angels|title=Evil Angels|work=SBS Movies|access-date=2018-08-17|language=en}} ''[[Return Home]],''{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/movies/video/11719235955/Return-Home|title=Return Home|work=SBS Movies|access-date=2018-08-17|language=en}} ''[[The Piano]]''{{Cite news|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/movies/video/11704387789/The-Piano-Review|title=The Piano: Review|work=SBS Movies|access-date=2018-08-17|language=en}}'', and [[Lantana (film)|Lantana]].''{{Cite news|url=https://ozflicks.wordpress.com/2016/09/13/what-david-and-margaret-say-about-400-oz-movies/|title=What Margaret and David say about 500 Oz Movies|date=2016-09-13|work=ozflicks|access-date=2018-08-17|language=en-US}} ==In other media== Pomeranz and Stratton both appeared in a parody of themselves and ''At the Movies'' in the fourth episode of the ABC show ''[[Lawrence Leung's Choose Your Own Adventure]]''.[http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2009/04/choose-your-own-margaret-david.html "Choose your own Margaret & David"] by David Knox, TVtonight (12 April 2009) They have also appeared in the ABC shows ''[[The Chaser's War on Everything]]'',{{YouTube|id=NhOt3vZJ-wk&t=15m31s|title=''The Chaser's War on Everything'', season 2, episode 17, at 15:31}} ''[[Review with Myles Barlow]]'' and ''[[Good Game (television series)|Good Game]]''. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.abc.net.au/atthemovies/}} * {{IMDb title|id=0421288|title=At the Movies}} * {{tv.com show|at-the-movies|At the Movies}} [[Category:Australian non-fiction television series]] [[Category:Australian Broadcasting Corporation shows]] [[Category:ABC News and Current Affairs]] [[Category:Film criticism television series]] [[Category:2004 Australian television series debuts]] [[Category:2014 Australian television series endings]] [[Category:2000s Australian television series]] [[Category:2010s Australian television series]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Cinema of Australia]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/117.136.89.240|117.136.89.240]] ([[User talk:117.136.89.240|talk]]) to last revision by Flickerd. ([[WP:TW|Twinkle]])
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} '''[[Australian rules football]]''' has been played in '''[[People's Republic of China|China]]''' since the 1990s. Interest in Australian football in China received a boost after the [[Australian Football League|AFL]], the premier professional football competition in [[Australia]], invested in an AFL exhibition match in Shanghai in 2010, an AFL academy in 2011, and built a dedicated AFL oval in Tianjin in 2011.
==Senior clubs== There are a number of senior clubs spread throughout China, including in the bigger cities of [[Beijing]], [[Shanghai]], Guangzhou and [[Tianjin]], as well as [[Auskick]] programs in other cities such as [[Suzhou]], [[Jiangsu]] province.
==Regional clubs and programs==
===Beijing=== Australian rules was first played in [[Beijing]] in 2004, with the foundation of the Australian Expatriate team, the Beijing Bombers.
The Bombers play an annual China Cup series against the other Australian expatriate team the Shanghai Tigers, as well as starting a 3-team metro league known as the Beijing AFL in 2009.
===Dongguan===
In late 2011 into early 2012 Darrell Egan Founded the Dongguan Panther Blues team at a middle school in Humen Dongguan. The team is also known in Australia as the China Blues consists of 15 to 18 years old student players, with some old school players up to the age of 20. The team went on to play Chinese teams of locals which formed in mid 2013 and is now coached under team's original captain Lin Honghue (Leighton Lin). Darrell Egan now acts as the team's Australian Liaison manager. The Dongguan Panther Blues established the first Chinese team of locals in China in 2014. Carlton Blues player Wally Koochew (See Below) being a pioneer as the first Chinese player in VFL/AFL history the Dongguan Blues team are also the pioneers in China.<ref>https://www.facebook.com/auschina.footy</ref><ref>http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-07-13/an-afl-takes-off-in-china/4128370</ref><ref>http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/international/radio/program/connect-asia/expat-promotes-australian-rules-football-in-chinas-dongguan/978706</ref>
===Guangzhou=== The Guangzhou Scorpions Australian expatriate team was formed in 2010, playing matches against the Hong Kong Dragons and Macau Lightning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hk-dragons.com/index.php/blog/2010/12/12/dragons-finish-season-on-a-high/ |title=Dragons Finish Season on a High |work=Hong Kong Dragons |first=Paul |last=Mallia |date=12 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711172206/http://www.hk-dragons.com/index.php/blog/2010/12/12/dragons-finish-season-on-a-high/ |archivedate=2011-07-11 |df= }}</ref>
===Hong Kong=== The Hong Kong Dragons Australian expatriate team was formed in 1990, and have been one of Asia's most successful Australian rules football clubs since this time. The Dragons play against other Asian teams regularly and have competed at all [[Asian Australian Football Championships]] to date.
Auskick, the Australian football program for juniors, grew in the early 2000's after two Victorian expatriate families managed to secure official support and equipment from the AFL in Australia. Players trained at the iconic grounds at Happy Valley as well as the Australian International School Hong Kong (AISHK).<ref>http://www.scmp.com/article/594722/australian-football-gathers-steam</ref>
A second Australian expatriate team in the [[Pokfulam]] region of Hong Kong was in existence in 2010, playing as the Pokfulam Vikings and conducting some matches against the Dragons.<ref name=HKMac>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldfootynews.com/article.php/20100505112623218 |title=First Hong Kong-Macau local derby this weekend |work=World Footy News |date=6 May 2010 |first=Aaron |last=Richard}}</ref>
The Dragons also coordinate an [[Auskick]] juniors program.
===Macau=== Australian football began in [[Macau]] in 2009, with the introduction of [[Auskick]] and matches at the International School of Macau. The Macau Lightning Australian expatriate senior team debuted in 2010, with matches against the Hong Kong Dragons and Pokfulam Vikings.<ref name=HKMac /> They made their first Asian Championships appearance in Shanghai in October 2010, but failed to win any matches at the tournament.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldfootynews.com/article.php/20101007184305969 |title=hanghai to host Asian Championships |work=World Footy News |date=7 October 2010 |first=Ash |last=Nugent}}</ref>
===Shanghai=== A club was established in [[Shanghai]] under the name of the Shanghai Tigers in 2002. The Tigers have a playing list consisting mainly of expatriate Australians, with some British, American and South African players as well.
===Suzhou=== The city of [[Suzhou]] does not currently have any senior clubs, although in 2007, 18 schools had introduced the sport into their curriculum.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldfootynews.com/article.php?story=2007102700024085 |title=Dees see China investment already bearing fruit |work=World Footy News |date=27 October 2007 |first=Brett |last=Northey}}</ref>
===Tianjin=== The sister city relationship between [[Tianjin]] and [[Melbourne]] saw the beginnings of football development in 2005.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldfootynews.com/article.php/20050919055630735 |title=Melbourne link to China development |work=World Footy News |date=19 September 2005 |first=Peter |last=Parry}}</ref> By 2007, a development organisation called the AFL China had been formed, with [[Tianjin Normal University]] having two Australian football teams at its main campuses.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldfootynews.com/article.php/20071121172019646 |title=Beijing defeat Shanghai and Tianjin found second team in big week for Chinese footy |work=World Footy News |date=21 November 2007 |first=Aaron |last=Richard}}</ref>
The Tianjin program is sponsored by the [[Melbourne Football Club]] and the [[Melbourne City Council]], through links formed by former Melbourne Lord Mayor [[John So]].
===Xinjiang=== A junior program called the Gobi Desert AFL existed at a primary school in [[Hami City|Hami]], [[Xinjiang]] in the 1990s, but this has now disappeared.
==International Competition== A representative team mainly consisting of expat Australians in China has competed under the names China Blues and China Reds in International fixtures and Asian AFL Championships. The first national representative team composed entirely of Chinese nationals appeared as the China Red Demons at the [[2008 Australian Football International Cup]].
===International Cup=== *[[2002 Australian Football International Cup|2002]]: Did not compete *[[2005 Australian Football International Cup|2005]]: Did not compete *[[2008 Australian Football International Cup|2008]]: 15th *[[2011 Australian Football International Cup|2011]]: 5th (Division Two) *[[2014 Australian Football International Cup|2014]]: 4th (Division Two)
==Chinese community in Australia== [[File:Image-koochew1908.jpg|thumb|right|Wally Koochew of Carlton]] [[Chinese Australians]] have been playing Australian rules football since the late 19th century. The [[Ballarat]] [[Chinese Football Premiership]] was covered extensively between 1892 and 1896, in local newspapers.<ref>'A death blow to the white Australia policy': Australian rules football and the Chinese community in Victoria, 1892-1908</ref>
[[Wally Koochew]] played four games for [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] during 1908, in the [[Australian Football League|Victorian Football League]] (VFL), becoming the league's first Australian player with Chinese heritage.
Between 1973 and 1985, [[Les Fong]] was a prominent and acclaimed player in the [[Western Australian Football League]] (WAFL), which held equal status to the VFL during that period. He was also selected for six [[interstate matches in Australian Football#State of origin|State of Origin]] games for the [[Western Australia Australian rules football team|Western Australian team]], including the first such game (1977).<ref>[http://www.wafootball.com.au/resources/doc_download/17-wa-state-representatives [[West Australian Football Commission]], 2012, ''Western Australian Interstate Football Representatives'' 1904 - 2011] (19 May 2012)</ref> Fong played 284 games for [[West Perth Football Club|West Perth]] in the WAFL and remains the club's longest-serving captain (1980–85).
In August 2012, [[Lin Jong]], a player with the {{AFL WB}} of [[Taiwanese people|Taiwanese]] and [[Chinese people in East Timor|East Timorese]] background, was elevated to the senior list and made his debut against {{AFL Ric}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/afl/more-news/lin-jong-elevated-to-the-western-bulldogs-senior-list/story-e6frf9jf-1226446852478|title=Lin Jong elevated to the Western Bulldogs senior list|date=9 August 2012|first=Sam|last=Landsberger|work=[[Herald Sun]]}}</ref>
In March 2016 Team China captain [[Chen Shaoliang]], 23, joined Port Adelaide on an AFL international scholarship for the season.<ref>http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/sport/afl/teams/port-adelaide/port-adelaide-signs-its-first-recruit-from-china/news-story/3dbfc5140ec5d5c6326d490736a79e09</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Aussie Rules Playing Nations links}} {{Australian Football International Cup}}

page.title: Avatar: The Last Airbender – Into the Inferno

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta2) ([[User:Josve05a|Josve05a]])
revision.text:
{{refimprove |date=August 2011}} {{Infobox video game |title = Avatar: The Last Airbender –
Into the Inferno |collapsible = |state = |image = Into the Inferno.jpg |caption = European box cover |developer = [[THQ Studio Australia]] |publisher = [[Play THQ]] |series = |released = {{vgrelease|NA|October 13, 2008}}{{vgrelease|AUS|October 30, 2008}}{{vgrelease|NZ|October 31, 2008}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20081006123251/http://www.gamesman.co.nz/product.php?id=9618]{{vgrelease|EU|October 31, 2008}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20080910022303/http://www.woolworths.co.uk/web/jsp/product/index.jsp?pid=51650882] |genre = Action, Adventure |modes = |platforms = [[Wii]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[PlayStation 2]] }} '''''Avatar: The Last Airbender – Into the Inferno''''' (known as '''''Avatar: The Legend of Aang – Into the Inferno''''' in Europe) is a [[video game]] based on the Nickelodeon animated TV series ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]''. Like the previous two games which were set in the [[Avatar: The Last Airbender (video game)|first]] and [[Avatar: The Last Airbender – The Burning Earth|second]] seasons, the game's setting is based upon the show's third and final season. The Wii version was released on October 13, 2008 in North America and on November 1, 2008 in the UK.[http://www.woolworths.co.uk/web/jsp/product/index.jsp?pid=51650882 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080910022303/http://www.woolworths.co.uk/web/jsp/product/index.jsp?pid=51650882 |date=September 10, 2008 }} A PS2 version is also available and was released on October 31, 2008 in the UK.{{Cite web |url=http://www.play.com/Games/Xbox360/4-/5985555/Avatar-The-Legend-Of-Aang-Into-The-Inferno/Product.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-04-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204123758/http://www.play.com/Games/Xbox360/4-/5985555/Avatar-The-Legend-Of-Aang-Into-The-Inferno/Product.html |archive-date=2009-02-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Gameplay== Gameplay styles vary on different platforms. In the Nintendo DS version, the characters have very large heads, giving the game a cartoonish feel. [[Katara (Avatar: The Last Airbender)|Katara's]] ice bridge ability returns from the previous games. [[Sokka|Sokka's]] boomerang is used to disintegrate out-of-reach objects or to solve puzzles; the player draws a path for the boomerang to follow. [[Toph]] can Earthbend small platforms to get over gaps with spikes and Aang can make Whirlwinds to either change directions of objects or to get them across gaps. The Nintendo Wii and Sony PlayStation 2 versions provide a completely different way to play. Fire balls, rocks and water can all be picked up by holding the B button and are guided using the primary controller (Wii Remote on Nintendo Wii) provided there is a nearby source. Aang can form a sphere of high winds (canonically called an "air ball") to break down obstacles and blow away objects by making a circle with the primary controller. Toph can lift up earth and throw it, pull earth out of walls and lift it up to make pillars. Katara can Bend water to put out fires and can freeze it into a block by shaking the secondary controller (Nunchuk on Nintendo Wii). Ice can also be pulled out of waterfalls and ice pillars can be made. Zuko can guide fire and burn things. Sokka throws his boomerang when the B button is pressed. Aang is unique, in that canonically he can bend all four elements, but only fights using Airbending. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | GR = 68.14% (DS){{cite web |url= http://www.gamerankings.com/ds/946163-avatar-the-last-airbender-into-the-inferno/ |title= Avatar: Into the Inferno (DS) |publisher= [[Gamerankings]] |accessdate= October 13, 2008}}
63% (WII){{cite web |url= http://www.gamerankings.com/wii/946162-avatar-the-last-airbender-into-the-inferno/ |title = Avatar: Into the Inferno (wii) |publisher= [[Gamerankings]] |accessdate= October 13, 2008}}
47.25% (PS2){{cite web |url= http://www.gamerankings.com/ps2/946164-avatar-the-last-airbender-into-the-inferno/ |title= Avatar: Into the Inferno (PS2) |publisher= Gamerankings |accessdate= October 13, 2008}} | MC = 65/100 (DS){{cite web |url= http://www.metacritic.com/game/ds/avatar-the-last-airbender---into-the-inferno |title= Avatar: Into the Inferno |publisher= [[Metacritic]] |accessdate= October 13, 2008}}
53/100 (WII){{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/wii/avatar---the-last-airbender-into-the-inferno |title= Avatar: Into the Inferno |publisher= [[Metacritic]] |accessdate= October 13, 2008 }}
48/100 (PS2){{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-2/avatar---the-last-airbender-into-the-inferno |title= Avatar: Into the Inferno |publisher= Metacritic |accessdate= October 13, 2008}} | IGN = 5.8/10 (DS){{cite web |url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2008/11/25/avatar-the-last-airbender-into-the-inferno-review |title= Avatar: Into the Inferno |publisher= [[IGN]] |accessdate= October 13, 2008}}
5/10 (PS2/WII){{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2008/10/29/avatar-the-last-airbender-into-the-inferno-review-2 |title= Avatar: Into the Inferno |publisher= [[IGN]] |accessdate= October 13, 2008}}
{{cite web |url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2008/10/29/avatar-the-last-airbender-into-the-inferno-review-2 |title= Avatar: Into the Inferno |publisher= IGN |accessdate= October 13, 2008}} }} The game received mixed reviews. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.thq.com/games/gameinfo.php?id=1340 ''Avatar: The Last Airbender - Into the Inferno'' at publisher THQ's website] {{Avatar: The Last Airbender}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Avatar: The Last Airbender - Into the Inferno}} [[Category:2008 video games]] [[Category:THQ games]] [[Category:Wii games]] [[Category:Nintendo DS games]] [[Category:PlayStation 2 games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Australia]] [[Category:Avatar: The Last Airbender games|Into the Inferno]]

{{Infobox video game |title = Baltic 1985: Corridor To Berlin |image = Baltic 1985 box front.jpg |caption = Box art |developer = [[Roger Keating]] |publisher = [[Strategic Simulations]] |released = {{vgrelease|NA|1984}} |genre = [[Computer wargame|Wargame]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]]
[[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Apple II]], [[Commodore 64]] }} '''''Baltic 1985: Corridor To Berlin''''' is a computer wargame published in 1984 by [[Strategic Simulations]]. Developed by [[Roger Keating]], it was the third in the "When Superpowers Collide" series. ==Summary== In 1985, after [[NATO]] halts a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] invasion of [[West Germany]], and a communist invasion of [[Saudi Arabia]] is thwarted by the American [[Rapid deployment force|Rapid Deployment Forces]], the Soviets rush forces from the West German front into [[Polish People's Republic|Poland]] to put down an anti-Soviet uprising. NATO takes advantage of the moment by invading East Germany to relieve the siege of [[West Berlin]] and evacuate its personnel trapped behind enemy lines. The player may choose to play either the NATO or Soviet forces, and can play in turns against another human component or against the computer. ==See also== *''[[Germany 1985]]'' *''[[RDF 1985]]'' *''[[Norway 1985]]'' ==External links== * {{MobyGames|id=/baltic-1985}} *[http://www.c64sets.com/set.html?id=22 Images of ''Baltic 1985'' box and manual] from C64Sets.com [[Category:1984 video games]] [[Category:Alternate history video games]] [[Category:Apple II games]] [[Category:Cold War video games]] [[Category:Commodore 64 games]] [[Category:Computer wargames]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Strategic Simulations games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Australia]] [[Category:Video games set in Europe]] {{strategy-videogame-stub}}

{{Infobox comic book title |image = Battle of the Atom.jpg |imagesize = |caption = {{Descript-cvr|Battle of the Atom||1|September 2013|¶ = y|art= [[Arthur Adams (comics)|Arthur Adams]]}} |alt = |publisher = [[Marvel Comics]] |startmo = September |startyr = 2013 |endmo = October |endyr = 2013 |mini = |run = |main_char_team = [[All-New X-Men|Past X-Men]]
[[Wolverine and the X-Men (comics)|Wolverine's Present X-Men]]
[[Uncanny X-Men|Cyclops's Present X-Men]]
[[X-Men|Future X-Men]] |writers = [[Brian Michael Bendis]]
[[Jason Aaron]]
[[Brian Wood (comics)|Brian Wood]] |artists = [[Frank Cho]]
[[Stuart Immonen]]
[[Chris Bachalo]]
[[David Lopez (artist)|David Lopez]]
[[Giuseppe Camuncoli]] |pencillers = |inkers = |letterers = |colorists = |sort = Battle of the Atom |nonUS = }} "'''Battle of the Atom'''" is a 10-part [[comic book]] [[Fictional crossover|crossover]] storyline published by [[Marvel Comics]] that debuted in September and October 2013 and ran through multiple X-Men books. The story involves the X-Men of the future traveling to present time in order to force the [[time-displaced X-Men]] to return to their rightful time, as their presence in the current timeline will result in disastrous consequences.Richards, Dave (September 5, 2013). [http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=47711 "'X-Men' Editor Lowe Fights the 'Battle of the Atom']. [[Comic Book Resources]]. == Publication history == ''Battle of the Atom'' was announced in April 2013. The story involves the X-Men of the future traveling to present time in order to force the [[All-New X-Men]] to return to their rightful time, as their presence in the current timeline will result in disastrous consequences.Truitt, Brian (September 8, 2013). [https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/2013/09/08/brian-michael-bendis-x-men-sunday-conversation/2773811/ "Sunday Geekersation: Bendis takes pride in his X-Men"]. ''[[USA Today]]''. [[Brian Michael Bendis]], writer of ''All-New X-Men'', stated that the use of [[time travel]] in the story is less important than the theme of characters exploring how the choices they make early in life affect them later on in life, in a manner similar to the 1986 feature film ''[[Peggy Sue Got Married]]''. Musing on the nature of fate, and how these ideas inspired both his previous comics work, and "Battle of the Atom" in particular, Bendis explained: {{quote|I get a lot of questions about this: Where would you see yourself in 10 years or what do you think the 12-year-old version of you would think of this? It seems to be on a lot of people's minds. When the X-Men are faced with all of this, you can't help but second-guess or really take hold of the choices you're making in life, and some people don't. They don't really think about the choices they're making, or you see someone in a relationship with someone and you go, 'Really, that's what you want in your life?' The X-Men can really show that to people in examining your future and such. It's about your own legacy and being the best version of yourself, and if I go down this road, will I be the best version of myself or will I derail completely? I've been writing about that since ''Jinx''. Literally, Jinx says, 'I'm on a road and I have no idea how I got here and I don't even know where the road I was supposed to be on is. I can't even see it.' When I was in college, I saw people not even sure why they were in the major they were in. I'll never forget, one of my neighbors was an astrophysicist, and he was sitting on the porch and he goes, "I hate astrophysics. Why am I doing this? I don't like it." And he was only a year away from graduating. The guy's haunted me all these years.}} == Plot == When Kitty Pryde's group of time displaced Original Five (O5) X-Men and Cyclops' Uncanny X-Men are forced to team up to stop an out of control new mutant, young Cyclops is killed by a Sentinel. He is resurrected moments later by one of Cyclops' recruits, who is a healer. However, in the brief moments that Young Cyclops was dead, the adult Cyclops blinked out of existence and the world around the two groups suddenly began to shudder and shake, as if reality was collapsing from the time paradox. This causes another round of debate from Wolverine's X-Men about returning the O5 to their proper place in the timeline. The debate is suddenly interrupted by the arrival of a group of older X-Men led by an aged Kitty Pryde, the grandson of Charles Xavier, and an adult Jean Grey (the time displaced O5 Jean Grey, having never returned to the past), dressed as the new Xorn. They seek to force the X-Men to go back to the past. Realizing that something does not seem right, O5 Jean escapes with O5 Cyclops. The X-Men and "Future X-Men" pursue, with Xorn explaining that a catastrophe will soon befall the X-Men if the O5 do not return to their original place in the timeline. The exact nature of that catastrophe is left ambiguous. O5 Jean & Scott eventually make contact with Cyclops team of Uncanny X-Men, and after some consideration Scott agrees to help his younger self and young Jean. Realizing that Scott's thinking on the matter is compromised, Emma Frost telepathically alerts the X-Men and Future X-Men of Young Jean's and Scotts location. However, upon seeing Xorn attack her younger self, Emma has a change of heart and attacks Xorn with the Cuckoos and O5 Jean. Xorn is able to defeat the combined powers of Emma and her Cuckoos, but O5 Jean is eventually able to defeat her. Xorn gives O5 Jean a glimpse of the future, a ploy on her part, which convinces O5 Jean that they need to go back to their proper place in the timeline. The three teams of X-Men part ways, with Cyclops unsure if this fight is really over. Magik, who is also suspicious of the motives of these new X-Men, travels to the future along with O5 Beast and O5 Iceman. It is discovered that these "Future X-Men" are really the "Future Brotherhood", and motives are purely self-serving. This new Brotherhood was created when Alison Blaire, also known as the X-Man Dazzler, is elected president and quickly assassinated, with the identity of the assassin unrevealed. The true "Future X-Men" agree to travel back in time and confront the Brotherhood. Upon arriving at the X-mansion with O5 Jean, Scott and Angel, it is discovered that the O5 Beast and Iceman are in the future. The Brotherhood realizes that they will soon have to fight Cyclops's team and the true "Future X-Men", and accelerate their plans. It is revealed that the "Future Kitty Pryde" is really Raze, the shape shifting son of Mystique and Wolverine. They attack the original X-Men, including an incapacitated Wolverine. Raze is able to infiltrate Scott's team and capture O5 Iceman and Beast. The O5 X-Men are brought to Beast's time machine and an attempt is made to send them back in time. However, an unknown force prevents this process from being completed. As the other Brotherhood members are overwhelmed by the Uncanny X-Men and the Future X-Men, the surviving Brotherhood members flee to Cape Citadel, the site of the first battle between the O5 X-Men and Magneto. The Brotherhood attacks the military to attract the attention of S.H.I.E.L.D. The fully united force of the Uncanny X-Men, Wolverine's team of X-Men, and the "Future" X-Men arrive to stop them. Xorn is able to control the S.H.I.E.L.D. weapon systems on site and launch the government Sentinels, which were being created in secret. The X-Men defeat the government Sentinels, and turn their attention to Xorn. She is able to hold the combined forces off, but her powers overload and she explodes. The exact catastrophe that befalls the X-Men due to the O5's presence is not revealed. The Future X-Men return to their proper place in the timeline with their casualties. The whereabouts of the Brotherhood member Raze is unknown. The O5 X-Men, due to being nearly forced to go back in time, decide to leave the Jean Grey School and join the Uncanny X-Men. Kitty Pryde, disgusted that the modern X-Men tried to send the original five back by force, even hunting Cyclops and Jean down like criminals, quits and joins the O5 Team to continue to mentor them. ==Cast== O5 X-Men *[[Jean Grey]] (Past) *[[Cyclops (Marvel Comics)|Cyclops]] (Past) *[[Beast (comics)|Beast]] (Past) *[[Iceman (comics)|Iceman]] (Past) *[[Warren Worthington III|Angel]] (Past) Wolverine's X-Men *[[Wolverine (character)|Wolverine]] *[[Storm (Marvel Comics)|Storm]] *[[Beast (comics)|Beast]] *[[Iceman (comics)|Iceman]] *[[Rachel Grey|Marvel Girl ll]] *[[Psylocke]] *[[Rogue (comics)|Rogue]] *[[Shadowcat]] *[[Jubilee (comics)|Jubilee ll]] Cyclops's X-Men *[[Cyclops (Marvel Comics)|Cyclops]] *[[Emma Frost]] *[[Magneto (comics)|Magneto]] *[[Magik (comics)|Magik]] *Tempus ll *Three-In-One *Triage *Benjamin Deeds *[[Goldballs]] Future Brotherhood *Xorn lll (older Jean Grey, from the time-displaced O5) *Charles Xavier II, son of Charles Xavier and Mystique *Beast *Raze Darkholme, son of Wolverine and Mystique *[[Molly Hayes]] *Ice Thing, sentient creation of Iceman *Deadpool Future X-Men *Colossus, wielding Magik's Demon Blade *Wolverine (Jubilee ll) *Phoenix (Kid Omega) *Ice Wizard (Iceman) *Wiccan, the new [[Doctor Strange|Sorcerer Supreme]] *Kymera, daughter of Storm *Sentinel X (Shogo, Jubilee's adopted son) ==Titles involved== '''September 2013''' *Part 1: ''X-Men: Battle of the Atom'' #1 *Part 2: ''[[All-New X-Men]]'' vol. 1 #16 *Part 3: ''[[X-Men (comic book)|X-Men]]'' vol. 4 #5 *Part 4: ''[[Uncanny X-Men]]'' vol. 3 #12 *Part 5: ''[[Wolverine and the and the X-Men'' vol. 1 #37 *Part 10: ''X-Men: Battle of the Atom'' #2 ==Critical reception== {{expand section|date=December 2014}} "Battle of the Atom" has been reviewed by a number of different websites, including [[IGN]],Schedeen, Jesse (August 27, 2013). [www.ign.com/articles/2013/08/27/x-men-battle-of-the-atom-1-advance-review "Time travel and dystopian futures? Just another day in the X-office."]. [[IGN]]. [[iFanboy]]Montgomery, Paul (April 28, 2013). [http://ifanboy.com/articles/c2e2-2013-bendis-aaron-and-wood-wage-x-men-battle-of-the-atom/ "C2E2 2013: Bendis, Aaron and Wood Wage X-MEN: BATTLE OF THE ATOM [UPDATE]"]. [[iFanboy]]. and [[Comic Book Resources]].Zawisza, Doug (August 28, 2013). [http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=user_review&id=6378 "X-Men: Battle of the Atom #1"]. [[Comic Book Resources]]. ==Mobile game== In January 2014, a mobile card game based on the event was released for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] devices. ==Collected editions== {| class="wikitable" width="100%" |- ! width="25%" | Title ! width="40%" | Material collected ! width="5%" | Pages ! width="15%" | Publication date ! width="15%" | ISBN |- | ''X-Men: Battle of the Atom'' | ''X-Men: Battle of the Atom'' (vol. 1) #1-2; ''All-New X-Men'' (vol. 1) 16-17; ''X-Men'' (vol. 4) #5-6; ''Uncanny X-Men'' (vol. 3) #12-13; ''Wolverine and the X-Men'' (vol. 1) #36-37 | 148 | January 21, 2014 | Hardcover: {{ISBNT|978-0785189060}} Paperback: {{ISBNT|978-1846535727}} |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{X-Comics}} {{Marvel events}} [[Category:Marvel Comics storylines]] [[Category:2013 comics debuts]]

{{Expand German|date=March 2015}} {{refimprove|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = CDV Software Entertainment AG | logo = Logo_cdv.svg | vector_logo = | type = [[Aktiengesellschaft]] | genre = | foundation = 1989 | founder = Wolfgang Gäbler | location_city = | location_country = | location = [[Bruchsal]], [[Germany]] | origins = | key_people = | area_served = | industry = [[Computer and video game industry]] | products = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = Around 100{{cite web |url=http://www.cdv.de/index.php?sid=en030000 |title=cdv Company Profile |website=cdv.de |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041207231056/http://www.cdv.de/index.php?sid=en030000 |archivedate=2004-12-07}} | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | owner = | company_slogan = | homepage = | dissolved = 2010 | footnotes = }} [[File:Cdv-logo-old.svg|thumb|Old logo.]] '''CDV Software Entertainment AG''' (formerly '''CDV Software GmbH''', stylized as '''cdv''') was a [[Germany|German]] [[Video game publisher|publisher]] of [[video game]]s founded 1989 in [[Karlsruhe]]. On April 17, 2000 cdv became a Frankfurt [[stock market]] traded company.[https://www.boersen-zeitung.de/index.php?li=70&l=0&isin=DE000A0MF053&portrait=LANGPROFIL] In the beginning of the 2000s CDV was the biggest German publisher in the German video game market. They opened a UK office in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/cdv-software-opens-uk-office|title=cdv Software opens UK office|last=Martin|first=Matt|work=[[Gamesindustry.biz]]|date=2008-07-22|accessdate=2014-12-16}} In 2010, [[VG247]] reported that they filed for preliminary insolvency when [[SouthPeak Games]] failed to pay a settlement.{{cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2010/04/15/cdv-software-files-for-preliminary-insolvency/|title=cdv Software files for preliminary insolvency|last=Nunneley |first=Stephany |work=[[VG247]] |date=2010-04-15 |accessdate=2014-12-16}} == Published titles ==
* [[American Conquest]] ** [[American Conquest#Fight Back|Fight Back]] (1. [[Expansion pack|Add-on]] for American Conquest) ** [[American Conquest#Divided Nation|Divided Nation]] (2. Add-on for American Conquest) * [[Blitzkrieg (video game series)|Blitzkrieg]] * [[Codename: Panzers#Codename: Panzers – Phase 1|Codename: Panzers Phase 1]] * [[Codename: Panzers#Codename: Panzers – Phase 2|Codename: Panzers Phase 2]] * Combat Mission 1-3 * [[Cossacks: European Wars]] ** [[Cossacks: European Wars#Cossacks: Art of War|Cossacks: The Art of War]] (1. Add-on for Cossacks) ** [[Cossacks: European Wars#Cossacks: Back to War|Cossacks: Back to War]] (2. Add-on (Stand-Alone) for Cossacks) * [[Cossacks II: Napoleonic Wars]] ** [[Cossacks II: Napoleonic Wars#Expansion pack|Cossacks II: Battle for Europe]] (Add-on (Stand-Alone) for Cossacks II) * Die Römer * [[Duke Nukem]] * [[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]] * [[Doom 2]] * [[Hammer & Sickle]] * [[Heaven and Hell (video game)|Heaven and Hell]] * [[Jackass: The Game]] * [[Lula: The Sexy Empire]] * [[Lula 3D]] * [[Night Watch (video game)|Nightwatch]] * [[Project: Nomads]] * [[Rosso Rabbit in Trouble]] * [[Santa Claus in Trouble]] * [[Shadowgrounds Survivor]] * [[Sudden Strike]] * [[ÜberSoldier]] * [[Breed (video game)|Breed]]
